content: I recently had a discussion around strict aliasing, and a colleague mentioned that strict aliasing was added to the C standard at some point. My understanding was that strict aliasing had always been a consequence of the standard definition and that it took some while for compiles to start using/abusing this property. Anyone know more about the origins of strict aliasing in C?
I believe it was added to be able to compete on performance level with fortran which requires arrays to never alias.
Any clue which version it was added in?
Eh, I got confused with the restrict keyword. What I said applies to restrict, not strict aliasing.
strict-aliasing was formally added in C99, it was kinda-sorta implied in C90 but only eh.
I think officially it originated in the C++ standard?
And then C99 copied it from there
Hmm maybe I'm wrong, C90 has basically the same wording as C99 (https://kristerw.blogspot.com/2017/07/strict-aliasing-in-c90-vs-c99-and-how.html)

Yeah.
There were arguments against adding strict-aliasing whatsoever but as I understand it those arguments happened in 1988, basically.
And there was just enough hemming and hawwing about what it meant until C99 hammered down all the corners.
